Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Fundamental Investigation of Fire Initiation and Fire Behavior in Sparse Vegetation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
0932842
Fletcher

The purpose of this collaborative research project is to develop advanced modeling technology for describing fire initiation and propagation in vegetation with low canopy bulk density. The ability to predict the spread of wildland fires is paramount in protecting life, property, and natural resources. Current operational models predict overall fire behavior well for the conditions for which the model was correlated (e.g., dead fuel beds), but they do not perform as well for live bushes or trees with high moisture content. Detailed physical models, at either laboratory or landscape scale, require improved sub-grid scale models of combustion, especially to describe fire behavior in vegetation that does not act like a dense fuel bed due to the relative sparseness of the vegetation. This technology will be based on fundamental combustion measurements of live fuels, but it will apply to models of landscape-scale fires. The research objective will be achieved via four inter-related tasks: (1) flame propagation measurements in live leaves and small branches, (2) fire spread measurements in shrubs for varying bulk densities, (3) flame propagation models of bushes and trees, and (4) multi-bush fire behavior models.

The research will provide a cohesive picture of the phenomenon of fire spread starting from ignition of a single fuel element, such as a leaf, to a self-sustaining fire spreading through a larger fuel array such as a forest. The fundamental physical and chemical processes investigated are also relevant to the problem of surface fire propagation leading to ignition of crown fires. An improved fundamental understanding of fire behavior in sparse vegetation will be beneficial in promoting better predictive capability in other areas such as fire safety or arson investigation pertaining to identifying ignition sources. Gaining an understanding of the conditions under which a fire may or may not propagate within a sparse vegetative fuel bed will provide understanding of how to control fire spread more effectively in these fuel types through improved fuel management.

This research program focused on fire behavior in sparse vegetation will stimulate interest in graduate studies among ethnic minorities and women in engineering at both at UCR and BYU by providing a new and innovative means of exploring ignition and combustion from single fuel elements to fire spread through multiple fuel elements. Graduate and undergraduate students trained at UCR and BYU will have the unique opportunity to interact closely with scientists at the USDA Forest Service laboratories in Riverside and Montana. This research has the potential to be used by international organizations concerned with fire spread in shrub lands which includes Australia, countries surrounding the Mediterranean Sea, South Africa, and Chile.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large wildland fires in the western states such as California, Texas, Arizona, and Utah have ravaged millions of acres and destroyed hundreds of homes. Many of these fires have occurred in live shrub-like vegetation, such as the chaparral in Southern California, sagebrush and juniper stands in Utah, and mesquite in Texas. Past research efforts have developed modeling tools for describing fire spread in dead grass or in tree canopies, but relatively little research has been performed to describe fire spread in live shrubs.

The research performed in this collaborative study between Brigham Young University (BYU) and the University of Alabama at Huntsville (UAH) was focused on fire behavior in live shrubs from Utah and southern California. Experimental research has spanned the scale from burning individual freshly-cut leaves in a well-controlled burner environment to burning a stand of freshly-cut branches in a wind tunnel. The leaf burning experiments at BYU have resulted in statistical information on key fire behavior characteristics such as the time to ignition, the maximum flame height, and the duration of the flame. These fire behavior characteristics were correlated to leaf characteristics such as species, moisture content, and leaf dimensions.

The wind tunnel experiments were conducted with the cut branches standing vertically rather than lying in a bed, as studied by other researchers. Thresholds of moisture content that permitted fire spread through a 6-foot long bed were explored for both manzanita and chamise species. Flame spread rate, flame height and angle, and total mass loss were recorded for comparison with models. Infrared images were obtained to determine temperatures of leaves and stems in the vicinity of the flame. In some high moisture cases the flame extinguished, and some partially-burned leaves were shown to still contain moisture even though ignition had occurred.

The leaf combustion correlations were incorporated into a semi-empirical flame propagation model, where flame propagation occurred by flame impingement on a neighboring leaf. This model requires geometrical placement of leaves in a typical shrub, so geometrical representations of shrubs of interest were developed, including Utah species (sagebrush, canyon maple, gamble oak, and juniper) and California species (manzanita, chamise, scrub oak, and ceanothus). The two non-broadleaf species (chamise and juniper) required development of a special method to describe the shrub geometry based on a form of fractal theory called L-systems. The semi-empirical shrub combustion model requires substantially less time than a comprehensive computational fluid dynamics model, and has shown the ability to describe many important fire behavior characteristics as a function of wind speed, bulk density of the shrub, and method of ignition. The model was tested versus the fire behavior characteristics observed in the wind tunnel at the PSW Research Station Forest Fire Laboratory in Riverside, California. Results of the modeling study were very encouraging, but illustrated the need for better models of the coalescence of flames from individual leaves in a three-dimensional geometry. This type of model will be important in the development of a sub-grid model for detailed modeling of a landscape, such as a hill or mountain. The semi-empirical model can also aid in the refinement of fire spread models used to develop containment plans for large wildland fires. Results from this project will also aid in describing the cautionary measures that should be taken with the vegetation surrounding houses and other structures in the wildland urban interface.
